case_name: Madhaorao Phalke v. State of Madhya Bharat

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 84 of 1954 is an appeal from the judgment and order dated September 1, 1954, of the former Madhya Bharat High Court in Civil Misc. Case No. 11 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 84 of 1954. Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 1, 1954, of the former Madhya Bharat High Court in Civil Misc. Case No. 11 of 1952.

facts.text: Appellant Madhaorao Phalke describes himself as an Ekkan claiming to receive Rs. 21/8/- per month from the State of Madhya Bharat.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Madhaorao Phalke describes himself as an Ekkan and claims that as such Ekkan he and his ancestors have been receiving the monthly payment of Rs. 21/8/-from the State of Madhya Bharat.

facts.text: Appellant's ancestors accompanied the Scindias to Gwalior from Maharashtra about 200 years ago and rendered military service.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the appellants ancestors had accompanied the Scindias to Gwalior from Maharashtra about 200 years ago, and had rendered military service in conquering the territory of Gwalior.

facts.text: Appellant's ancestors were granted a fixed monthly amount in recognition of military service, received by family for generations.

anchor.surface_text: In recognition of this service the appellants ancestors were granted a fixed amount of money per month, and this amount has been received by the appellants family for several generations past.

facts.text: Right to receive the amount recognized by Rulers of Gwalior in Kalambandis of 1912 and 1935.

anchor.surface_text: The right to receive this amount has been recognised by the Rulers of Gwalior in several statutes, orders, rules or regulations having the force of statutes amongst them are the Kalambandis of 1912 and 1935.

facts.text: On April 18, 1952, Government of Madhya Bharat issued executive order terminating payment to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: On April 18, 1952, the Government of Madhya Bharat issued an executive order terminating the said payment to the appellant that is why the appellant had to file the present petition

facts.text: Appellant filed petition under Art. 226 in High Court of Madhya Bharat against State and Revenue Department.

anchor.surface_text: that is why the appellant had to file the present petition in the High Court of Madhya Bharat against the State of Madhya Bharat and the Government of Madhya Bharat, Revenue Department, respondents 1 and 2 respectively under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Petition prayed for writ of mandamus or direction to forbear from giving effect to executive order.

anchor.surface_text: In this petition the appellant bad prayed for an order that a writ in the nature of mandamus, or in the alternative an appropriate direction or order be issued calling upon the respondents to forbear from giving effect to the said executive order.

facts.text: Respondents claimed payment was emoluments for military service, not property, and Kalambandis not existing law under Art. 372.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents case was that the payment made to the appellants ancestors and to him was by way of emoluments for military service and did number constitute property, and that the Kalambandis on which the appellant relied did number constitute an existing law under Art. 372.

facts.text: Ten other persons filed similar petitions, all eleven tried together by Full Bench of Madhya Bharat High Court: Shinde CJ, Dixit and Newaskar JJ.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that along with the appellant ten other persons had filed similar petitions making prayers for similar writs or orders against the respondents and their pleas were similarly challenged by the respondents. All the eleven petitions were accordingly tried together.

facts.text: High Court dismissed all petitions holding Kalambandis were administrative orders, not law.

anchor.surface_text: All the three learned judges agreed in holding that the Kalambandis on which the petitioners had rested their case were orders issued by the Ruler for the purpose of reorganising the scheme of administration and that they did number amount to law or regulation having the force of law.

facts.text: Appellant obtained certificate under Art. 133(1)(c) and appealed to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then applied for and obtained a certificate from the High Court under Art. 133 1  c  of the Constitution, and it is with the said certificate that he has come to this Court in the present appeal.

facts.text: On March 31, 1958, appeal heard by Supreme Court and remitted to High Court for additional evidence on whether Kalambandis were statutes or administrative orders.

anchor.surface_text: When this appeal was heard by this Court on March 31, 1958, it was conceded by both the parties that it would be better that they should be allowed to adduce additional evidence before the question of law which was undoubtedly one of general importance, was decided by this Court.

facts.text: After remand, High Court majority (Abdul Hakim Khan and Newaskar JJ) found Kalambandis were regulations having force of law; Krishnan J dissented.

anchor.surface_text: Abdul Hakim Khan and Newaskar, JJ., have found in favour of the appellant and have held that the Kalambandis in question were regulations having the force of law in the State of Gwalior at the material time Krishnan, J., has taken a contrary view.

facts.text: Ekkans were class of horsemen, single volunteers bringing own horses and accoutrements, part of Peshwas Cavalry.

anchor.surface_text: These Ekkans, it appears, were a class of horsemen who formed part of the Peshwas Cavalry along with Silledars. They were single volunteers and they brought with them their own horses and accoutrements.

facts.text: Other petitioners were Silledars whose ancestors part of Maharatta Cavalry, brought own horses and weapons, known as Paigadars.

anchor.surface_text: The other petitioners claimed to be Silledars whose ancestors formed part of the Maharatta Cavalry. These Silledars were troopers who brought in their own horses and weapons. They brought bodies of troops armed and equipped at their own expense. They were also known as Paigadars.

facts.text: Kalambandi of 1912 issued by Ruler Sir Madhavrao; Kalambandi of 1935 issued by Council after his death in 1925.

anchor.surface_text: The two Kalambandis in question were issued in 1912 A. D. and 1935 A. D. respectively. The first Kalambandi was issued by the Ruler Sir Madhavrao himself, whereas the second was issued by the Council which was then in charge of the administration of the State subsequent to the death of Sir Madhavrao which took place in 1925.

facts.text: States of Gwalior, Indore and Malwa integrated in 1948; Act No. 1 of 1948 continued existing laws.

anchor.surface_text: It is well-known that the States of Gwalior, Indore and Malwa integrated and formed a Union in 1948. After the Union was thus formed Act No. 1 of 1948 was passed for the purpose of taking over the administration of the covenanting States.

facts.text: On September 19, 1950, notification issued by Commissioner Jagir Inams declaring Bachat payments handled by his office.

anchor.surface_text: On September 19, 1950, a notification was issued by the Commissioner, Jagir Inams, Court of Wards, Madhya Bharat, declaring that in the case of army personnel described in paragraph 1,

facts.text: Impugned order of April 18, 1952, Clause 5 stopped distribution of amounts to Silledars and Ekkans not covered by Clauses 1-4 from May 1, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Then followed the impugned order passed by respondent 1 on April 18, 1952. Clauses 1 to 4 of this order made provision for the continued payment to the persons specified thereunder. Clause 5, however, declared that the distribution of amounts to Silledars and Ekkans not covered by cls. 1 to 4 would be absolutely stopped from May 1, 1952.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Kalambandis constitute existing law under Art. 372, executive order invalid.

anchor.surface_text: It is not disputed that if the Kalambandis on which the appellants right is based are rules or regulations having the force of law the impugned executive order issued by respondent 1 would be invalid.

facts.text: Appeal allowed, High Court order set aside, writ issued in favour of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Since we have answered this question in favour of the appellant we must allow the appeal, set aside the order passed by the High Court and direct that a proper writ or order should be issued in favour of the appellant as prayed for by him.

There was numberconstitutional limi- tation upon the authority of the Ruler to act in any capacity he liked he would be the supreme legislature, the supreme judiciary and the supreme head of the executive, and all his orders, however issued, would have the force of law and would govern and regulate the affairs of the State including the rights of its citizens.

arguments.claim: If Kalambandis are rules/regulations having force of law, impugned executive order invalid; right under existing law cannot be extinguished by executive order

anchor.surface_text: It is not disputed that if the Kalambandis on which the appellants right is based are rules or regulations having the force of law the impugned executive order issued by respondent 1 would be invalid. The right guaranteed to the appellant by an existing law

holdings.text: In an absolute monarchy like Gwalior, the distinction between executive orders and legislative commands is merely academic; all orders issued by the Ruler, however issued, have the force of law.

anchor.surface_text: In dealing with the question as to whether the orders issued by such an absolute monarch amount to a law or regulation having the force of law, or whether they constitute merely administrative orders, it is important to bear in mind that the distinction between executive orders and legislative commands is likely to be merely academic where the Ruler is the source of all power. There was no constitutional limi- tation upon the authority of the Ruler to act in any capacity he liked he would be the supreme legislature, the supreme judiciary and the supreme head of the executive, and all his orders, however issued, would have the force of law and would govern and regulate the affairs of the State including the rights of its citizens.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ruler was source of all power with no constitutional limitations; acted as legislature, judiciary, executive; precedents like Ameer-un-Nissa Begum applied by analogy.

holdings.text: An order issued by an absolute monarch in an Indian State which had the force of law amounts to an existing law under Art. 372 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: It is also clear that an order issued by an absolute monarch in an Indian State which had the force of law would amount to an existing law under Art. 372 of the Constitution. Article 372 provides for the continuance in force of the existing laws which were in force in the territories of India immediately before the commencement of the Constitution,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art. 372 continues existing laws; Art. 366(10) defines broadly to include orders by those with legislative power; no material difference between 'existing law' and 'law in force' per Edward Mills precedent.

holdings.text: Even if Kalambandis did not amount to a quanun or law technically so called, they would nevertheless be orders or regulations which had the force of law in Gwalior and saved under Art. 372.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, even if it is held that the Kalambandis in question did not amount to a quanun or law technically so called, they would nevertheless be orders or regulations which had the force of law in the State of Gwalior at the material time, and would be saved under Art. 372. The question which then arises is whether these Kalambandis were regulations having the force of law at the material time.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Broad definition under Art. 366(10) and General Clauses Act s.3(29); applies even if not formal statute.

holdings.text: The Kalambandis must be treated as rules or regulations having the force of law.

anchor.surface_text: having regard to the contents of the two orders and the character of the provisions made by them in such a detailed manner it is difficult to distinguish them from statutes or laws in any event they must be treated as rules or regulations having the force of law. That is the finding recorded by Abdul Hakim Khan and Newaskar, JJ., and we think that the said finding is correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contents confer hereditary rights, regulate succession, adoption, mutation, restrictions on alienation; impress statutory character; High Court majority finding correct; not mere administrative.

holdings.text: If Kalambandis are rules or regulations having force of law, the impugned executive order is invalid as right under existing law cannot be extinguished by executive order.

anchor.surface_text: It is not disputed that if the Kalambandis on which the appellants right is based are rules or regulations having the force of law the impugned executive order issued by respondent 1 would be invalid. The right guaranteed to the appellant by an existing law cannot be extinguished by the issue of an executive order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not disputed by parties; follows from Art. 372 continuance of existing laws; executive cannot override statutory right.

anchor.surface_text: In Ameer-un-Nissa Begum v. Mahboob Begum  1 , this Court had to deal with the effect of a Firman issued by the Nizam, and it observed that so long as the particular Firman issued by the Nizam held the field that alone would govern and regulate the rights of the parties concerned though it would be annulled or modified by a later Firman at any time that the Nizam willed.

precedents.cited_proposition: Firman issued by the Nizam governs and regulates the rights of parties concerned until annulled or modified
precedents.cited_holding: so long as the particular Firman issued by the Nizam held the field that alone would govern and regulate the rights of the parties concerned though it would be annulled or modified by a later Firman at any time that the Nizam willed

precedents.citation: Director of Endowments, Government of Hyderabad v. Akram Ali  2

anchor.surface_text: What was held about the Firman issued by the Nizam would be equally true about all effective orders issued by the Ruler of Gwalior  Vide also Director of Endowments, Government of Hyderabad v. Akram Ali  2   . It is also clear that an order issued by an absolute monarch in an Indian State which had the force of law would amount to an existing law under Art. 372 of the Constitution.

precedents.case_name: Director of Endowments, Government of Hyderabad v. Akram Ali
precedents.cited_proposition: Orders issued by ruler of Indian State have force of law

precedents.citation: Edward Mills Co., Ltd., Beawar v. State of Ajmer  3

anchor.surface_text: In Edward Mills Co., Ltd., Beawar v. State of Ajmer  3 , this Court has held that there is no any material difference between the expressions existing law. and the law in force. The definition of an, existing law in Art. 366 10  as well as the definition of an Indian law contained in s. 3 29  of the General Clauses Act make this position clear .

precedents.case_name: Edward Mills Co., Ltd., Beawar v. State of Ajmer
precedents.cited_proposition: No material difference between existing law and law in force
precedents.cited_holding: there is no any material difference between the expressions existing law. and the law in force

anchor.surface_text: In dealing with the question as to whether the orders issued by such an absolute monarch amount to a law or regulation having the force of law, or whether they constitute merely administrative orders, it is important to bear in mind that the distinction between executive orders and legislative commands is likely to be merely academic where the Ruler is the source of all power. There was no constitutional limi- tation upon the authority of the Ruler to act in any capacity he liked he would be the supreme legislature, the supreme judiciary and the supreme head of the executive, and all his orders, however issued, would have the force of law and would govern and regulate the affairs of the State including the rights of its citizens.

Since we have answered this question in favour of the appellant we must allow the appeal, set aside the order passed by the High Court and direct that a proper writ or order should be issued in favour of

It is also clear that an order issued by an absolute monarch in an Indian State which had the force of law would amount to an existing law under Art. 372 of the Constitution. Article 372 provides for the continuance in force of the existing laws which were in force in the territories of India immediately before the commencement of the Constitution,

Since we have answered this question in favour of the appellant we must allow the appeal, set aside the order passed by the High Court and direct that a proper writ or order should be issued in favour of

Therefore, even if it is held that the Kalambandis in question did not amount to a quanun or law technically so called, they would nevertheless be orders or regulations which had the force of law in the State of Gwalior at the material time, and would be saved under Art. 372. The question which then arises is whether these Kalambandis were regulations having the force of law at the material time.

Since we have answered this question in favour of the appellant we must allow the appeal, set aside the order passed by the High Court and direct that a proper writ or order should be issued in favour of

having regard to the contents of the two orders and the character of the provisions made by them in such a detailed manner it is difficult to distinguish them from statutes or laws in any event they must be treated as rules or regulations having the force of law. That is the finding recorded by Abdul Hakim Khan and Newaskar, JJ., and we think that the said finding is correct.

Since we have answered this question in favour of the appellant we must allow the appeal, set aside the order passed by the High Court and direct that a proper writ or order should be issued in favour of

It is not disputed that if the Kalambandis on which the appellants right is based are rules or regulations having the force of law the impugned executive order issued by respondent 1 would be invalid. The right guaranteed to the appellant by an existing law cannot be extinguished by the issue of an executive order.

Since we have answered this question in favour of the appellant we must allow the appeal, set aside the order passed by the High Court and direct that a proper writ or order should be issued in favour of
